document_metadata.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: TauRDΔK comprises the structural elements required for the pathologic assembly of tau filaments, and it causes reversible memory deficits and synapse loss in regulatable transgenic mice [11,25].

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: Analysis of sarkosyl extracts of brain homogenates of mice expressing the pro-aggregant repeat domain TauRDΔK revealed that oligomers are present, partly in a disulfide–cross-linked form (Supplementary Fig. 1).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: During early stages of assembly, there is some increase in ThS intensity, combined with a pronounced increase in ANSfluorescence (Fig. 2Aand B), which is due to oligomers, indicating a change in conformation without increase in beta-structure

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: As shown earlier, TauRDΔK-expressing mice display loss of neurons in the CA3 and other regions of the hippocampus [11,24].

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: By contrast, monomers of TauRDΔK even at 10 mM concentration did not cause any significant ROS increase (Fig. 5B).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: By contrast, there was no significant increase in the calcium level in cells treated with TauRDΔK monomers even at higher concentration (10 mM) (Fig. 5E and F, green curves).

citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: The fibril-treated cells (cross-linked with GA or not) did not reduce the spine density significantly (Fig 4C, bars 8 and 9).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: Recently, extracellular tau oligomers were shown to impair long term potentiation (LTP) and memory [40].

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: During the transition from oligomers to polymers, the ANS fluorescence remains roughly constant, whereas ThS fluorescence increases strongly (Fig. 2B)

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: To address this question, we first applied the oligomers directly after the purification of the protein eluting from the Butyl FF 16/ 10 column (without buffer exchange; 1, 5, and 10 mM) to SHSY5Y cells and observed a variety of toxic effects, including pronounced reduction in the cell viability (by MTT assay, Fig. 3A), increase in apoptotic cells (by Hoechst staining, Supplementary Fig. 4A), loss of mitochondrial membrane potential (by JC1 assay, Supplementary Fig. 4B), caspase 3/7 activation (Supplementary Fig. 4C-D), and cytochrome-c release (Supplementary Fig. 4), within 5 hours of incubation.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: Consistent with this, NeuN staining of the slices fixed after 48 hours of treatment with TauRDΔK oligomers revealed no reduction in the neuronal number in all regions of the hippocampus (CA1, CA3, and DG) (Fig. 3C and D, Supplementary Fig. 7), confirming that TauRDΔK oligomers do not cause cell death in the OHSC model as well.

citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: There was no significant change in the LDH release in oligomer-treated cells compared with controls indicating that TauRDΔK oligomers do not compromise the membrane integrity (Supplementary Fig. 5G-H).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: In this case, there was a dramatic loss (up to 50%) of spines in TauRDΔK oligomer-treated cells compared with monomer-treated cells (Fig. 4A and B, bar 3).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: Drebrin, a neuronal actin-binding protein involved in spinogenesis and synaptogenesis, was decreased by up to 60% consistent with the reduced number of spines (Fig. 4D, bars 3, 6, and 9).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: Endogenous tau protein retained its normal axonal localization and did not missort into the cell body and dendrites (Fig. 6A8), although there was a reduction in the spine density (Fig. 6B6) in the TauRDΔK oligomer-treated neurons.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: The results revealed that both TauRDΔK and TauFLΔK oligomers reduce the density of spines up to 50% compared with the buffer-treated cells.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: PSD-95, a marker of postsynaptic spines, decreased up to 50% in the TauRDΔK oligomer-treated cells, compared with buffer- and monomer-treated cells

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: Similarly, the GluR1 subunits of a-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid (AMPA) receptors (characteristic of mature spines and necessary for LTP and calcium signaling) decreased in the oligomer-treated samples up to 60%.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: Drebrin, a neuronal actin-binding protein involved in spinogenesis and synaptogenesis, was decreased by up to 60% consistent with the reduced number of spines (Fig. 4D, bars 3, 6, and 9).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: We also looked at the presynaptic protein synaptophysin, which was not significantly altered in TauRDΔK oligomer-treated cells compared with buffer- or monomer-treated cells (Fig 4D, bar 12). However, at higher concentration, synaptophysin tends to be reduced.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: We observed an oligomer-dependent increase in the ROS production in the mature rat primary hippocampal neurons in all cellular compartments (Fig. 5A).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: These findings suggest that the ROS production induced by extracellular TauRDΔK oligomers might cause the activation of NADPH oxidase complex

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: We indeed found that there is an overexpression (w15%) of Nox1 protein (a component of NADPH oxidase complex) by Western blot, suggesting the role of NADPH oxidase complex as a potential source of ROS

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: We indeed found that there is an overexpression (w15%) of Nox1 protein (a component of NADPH oxidase complex) by Western blot, suggesting the role of NADPH oxidase complex as a potential source of ROS

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: However, we did not find significant changes in the expression level of Nox2 protein (another component of NADPH oxidase complex) (Fig. 5C).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: The ratio of 340 to 380 nm in TauRDΔK oligomer-treated cells showed a steady concentration-dependent increase in the intracellular calcium with a maximum reached at 20 minutes of incubation with oligomers (10 mM) occurring in all cell compartments (Fig. 5D; arrows).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: We did not observe any increase in the phosphorylation of the tau repeat domain (as seen by the antibody 12E8) after treating the neurons with TauRDΔK oligomers.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: We also checked the phosphorylation of tau at other sites (e.g., using the antibody AT8, reacting only with the endogenous tau) and did not observe an increase in the phosphorylation.

citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: We also checked the phosphorylation of tau at other sites (e.g., using the antibody AT8, reacting only with the endogenous tau) and did not observe an increase in the phosphorylation.

links.evidence: Endogenous tau protein retained its normal axonal localization and did not missort into the cell body and dendrites (Fig. 6A8), although there was a reduction in the spine density (Fig. 6B6) in the TauRDΔK oligomer-treated neurons.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: Endogenous tau protein retained its normal axonal localization and did not missort into the cell body and dendrites (Fig. 6A8), although there was a reduction in the spine density (Fig. 6B6) in the TauRDΔK oligomer-treated neurons.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: Tau oligomers from TauRDΔK and TauFLΔK mice reduced the density of the synapses by w50%, whereas tau from wild-type mice had no effect on the density (Fig. 7G).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: We reasoned that microglia and other cell types in the hippocampus might act as mediators for the cytotoxicity caused by TauRDΔK oligomers, which could explain why cytotoxicity was not observed in the cell culture systems.

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: In our hands, these aggregated tau species formed in different conditions did not show any significant release of LDH when applied on the differentiated SH-SY5Y cells (Supplementary Fig. 8A), and they did not show a significant reduction in cell viability by the MTTassay (Supplementary Fig. 8B).

citation.journal: Alzheimer's & dementia : the journal of the Alzheimer's Association
citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

citation.name: Extracellular low-n oligomers of tau cause selective synaptotoxicity without affecting cell viability.

links.evidence: For comparison, in the case of Ab oligomers, only higher concentrations (w1 mM) cause an appreciable spine reduction of w30% (Fig. 4C, bar 3) (Zempel et al., 2010 [30]).
